PALESTINE - SYRIA MAIL SERVICE.–The fast steamers Prince Abbas and El Kahira leave Alexandria alternately on Saturdays at 4 p.m. for Jaffa (for Jerusalem), Caiffa (for Nazareth), Beyrouth (for Damascus), Tripoli, Alexandretta, and Mersina, continuing in alternate weeks to Larnaca (Cyprus).

SUDAN DIRECT MAIL SERVICE.–The mail steamers Dakahlieh and Kosseir leave Suez alternately on Wednesdays at 5 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakim in connection with the Sudan Government Railways express serice to Khartoum.
RED SEA COASTING MAIL SERVICE.–Mail steamers leave Suez on Mondays at 5 p.m. for Tor (for Sinai), Yambo and Jeddah, continuing in alternate weeks to Port Sudan, Suakim, Massowah, Hodeidah and Aden

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL.
div.p:
FORTHCOMING FLOTATIONS. TRAGEDY AT SEA. Gazette, February 25 1907
3 SAVOY PALACE HOTEL Nile steamer's Mishap
The Nile steamer Victoria burst a cylinder last week and was being towed by a tug when the latter sank. An engineer and a sailor were drowned.
The Late M. Felix Suaree
The bust of the late M. Felix Snares which is to be erected in the Umberto I. Hospital Cairo, by the Italian Benevolent Society, will be unveiled on March 17.
Field Day.
The British troops in Cairo were exercised to day, Major General Bollock, C.B., acting as umpire in-chief. The troops were divided into two forces, Red and Blue.
Band Performance.
By kind permission of Lieut. -Col. E. Herbert, M.V O, and officers, the string band 6th Inniskiiling Dragoons will play a programme of music at the National Hotel on Wednesday from 4 to 6 p.m.
Scene In the Esbekleh.
A horrible affair occurred in the Esbekieh quarter of Cairo on Thursday night. A man had a dispute with a barmaid in a bar there and poked the young woman's eye out with his walking-stick. He took to flight and has not been seen since.
Pleadings In English.
For the first time since the admission of English as one of the judicial languages recognised in the Mixed Courts a case was pleaded in English last week. This interesting event took place in the Commercial Court of the Mixed Court of Alexandria.
Capture of Smugglers.
On Friday night, the Coast Guard patrol seized 250 kilos of bashish, which was contained in eight sacks, on the Mex coast. At the same time, two of the smugglers, who had been in hiding bat were perceived by the patrol, were captured and placed under arrest.
Visit of Chaplain Central.
The R. Rev. bishop Taylor Smith, C.V.O., D.D., Chaplain General to the Faroes, will hold a confirmation on Tuesday, 26th inst. at 3 o’clock, in H.B.M's Garrison Church of St. George, Mustapha Pasha, and will also give an address at 6 o’clock in the Sailors’ and Soldiers Institute, Alexandria.
Bulgarian v. Creak.
The Descenesses’ Hospital at Alexandria is served by a Bulgarian milkman. Last week a Greek milkman went to the hospital and tried to get its custom. The Bulgarian heard of this competition and when he met the Greek in Saleh-ed Din street he attacked him with great ferocity. The Greek Consulate has opened an enquiry.
French Benevolent Society.
In accordance with the notice printed on the tickets, the lottery of the French Benevolent Society was drawn yesterday at 11 a.m. in the offices of the French Consulate, and in the presence of the members of the committee. The paintirg "La Mare aux Fees,” from Rigollot, fell to the lot of the owners of the ticket No. 533, Messrs, the Eastern Telegraph Co., Ltd.
"The Dean's Building.
Lady Cromer has kindly consented to lay the foundation stone of the “Dean’s Building” in Boulac. The Bishop in Jerusalem will con-duct the service. The ceremony will take place at 3 30 p.m. on Wednesday, 27th inst. The Building will consist of an English school, a large room for services, and flats for the head mistress and the assistant chaplain. The site,-the area of which is nearly 500 square metres, is situated a little to the left of where the Touret Badran crosses the Sharia Gheziret Badran as one goes down the latter road from the Shoubra Bridge.
An Epidemic of First.
Five fires occurred in Alexandria last night, and the Fire Brigade, under Yonsba-hi Waller, was busily engaged in coping with its many calls. The conflagrations took place at Bah Sidra, where a stable caught fire ; at Gheit el-Enab, on the south bank of the cana’, where a large straw store was burnt out ; in Rre Hamamil, where a beer shop was burnt; in Rue Abon Siri, where a Cafe caught fire; and lastly in a shop in Sisters-street. The most serious of these conflagrations was that on the canal. The fire broke out in a very large store of straw and it was only got under with great difficulty, the hose having to be laid across the canal under the water. The Fire Brigade was hard at work there for two hours, from 11.50, p.m. to 2 a.m.
steam Ploughing Machinery
Messre. Allen Alderson and Co, Limited, Alexandria and Cairo, have the pleasure to advise their friends and all persons interested in agriculture that Mr. Alfred Fowler, a director of Messrs. John Fowler and Co., Ltd., the well-known makers of steam ploughing machi-nery, is now in Cairo, as is also Mr. H C. Duburgnet. an engineer and expert of the same firm Mr.Fowler is staying at the Savoy Hotel, Cairo, and Mr. Duburguet at Shepheard’s. Both gentlemen, who have a large and varied experience all over the world, will be very pleased to inspect estates, at their own ex pense entirely, and advise as to the hast steam cultivating-machinery to be employed to obtain the best results at the cheapest cost. Messrs. John Fowler and Co., Ltd, will have a good display of their steam ploughing machinery ,at the Cairo 8how from ’he 28th February to the 4th March, and will be pleased to give every information to interested persons Hamburg and Anglo-American
NILE company.

River Transport of Goods between Alexandria end Cairo.
three sailings a-week.
• at Alexandria
ALEXANDRIA BONDED WAREHOUSE OJULTa countries. ENGINEERING COMPANIES- Among the masses of banking, financial. transport, industrial, technical and commercial companies, which are shortly to bo floated in Egypt, there are some interesting engineering oompanie0, details of which are given below.
WATSON AND COMPANY.
We hear on good authority that the well-know engineering firm of Messrs. William Watson and Co. of Alexandria is shortly to be turned into a limited liability company, under Egyptian law. Sir John R. Ellerman, Bart, of London (of ’he Ellerman Line of Steamers,) and Messrs. James Moss and Co., of Liverpool, (managers of the Moss S.S. Co., Limited) will be interested in the new company. Messrs R. J. Moss and Co., of Alexandria and Cairo, have been instrumental in bringing the negotiations to a conclusion with Mr. William Watson, of Banff, N.B., and with Mr. James Watson, of Alexandria. The business will be carried on as heretofore and considerable extensions are contemplated in the near future.
UNITED DELTA ENGINEERS. LIMITED.
Another important engineering company will shortly be floated in Egypt. 1t embraces the business of Messrs. Dowie and Company. of Port Said, Messrs. Murdoch and Templeton, of Mansourah, and the British Engineering Company, of Alexandria. It is to he registered in England under the title of the United Delta Engineers, Limited. The capital is to be £200,000 and there will be 12,000 founders’ shares of one shilling each. The company will be floated at the end of next month The board will consist of Dr. Milton, Colonel Gordon, Mr. Murdoch, Mr. Williamson, Mr. Bayne0, and Mr. Wilson, of London.
ANGLO EGYPTIAN COMMERCIAL CO. ]
The board of directors of this company is , composed as follows : S:r West Ridgeway, late Governor of Ceylon; dir E. Constantine Phipps, the earl of Fingall, Mr. Jacob Hessler, Mr. , Panos Alexakis, and Mr. Aristide Giro, of Alexandria.
COMPANY ACTIVITY.
The crowds of new flotations, which are to be placed before the Egyptian public in the near future, are giving a great deal of work to our local lawyer, and there is considerable activity being displayed in drawing up ’he numerous new prospectuses. Io London the printing firms have bad a great deal of extra work thrown on their hands by the phenomenal number of new Egyptian flotations and many firms are busily engaged in making plates for thousands of bearer warrants and founders’ shares, which are eventually to find their way into the possession of the Egyptian public. The shortest period in which a plate can he execu-. ted is a month and the average cost of a p'ate for a company is £5. These plates are engraved and the great London printers have artists specially for the work of sketching for the pistes. Many of the forthcoming flotations for the Egyptian market are very tasteful productions, with charming views of Egyptian mine, Pyramids, Sphinxes, Nile landscapes, and such like local scenes. Some of ’he new founders’ shares are sure to tempt the Egyptian investor j as they will be beautiful samples of the highest type of English artistic printing and the designs alone ought to send the shares up to a premium. The engraving departments of the London firm, who devote themselves to this class of work, have been extraordinarily busy for the last three months on Egyptian com panies", and Messrs Waterlow Bros, and Layton inform us that they have during the present season turned out some hundreds of thousands of bearer warrants fur Egypt. THE CENSUS OF EGYPT.
The time for the Census is drawing near. Many persons have already been appointed census enumerators ; others will be appointed shortly. Here and there there seems to be an impression that census work is very onerous and unpleasant, and is likely to interfere with the enumerators' regular duties. This im-pression is entirely erroneous. It is hoped that the following considerations will show that Government intend in every way to study the convenience of enumerators and make their work as public servants as easy as possible.
It is being arranged that, so far as practic- able, each person chosen to be an enumerator shall enumerate a block of houses near his home, that is to say, in a neighbourhood where he is likely to be more or less known as a friend and a neighbour.
Except for a few hours on a single night (that of the 29 h April, 1907) the enumeration can be done at leisure The preliminary work of writing up the schedules can be spread over six week, or more, and can be done by the enumerator a few minutes at a time when he is not otherwise engaged. It need not in any way interfere with his ordinary avocations,
, Printed instructions as to how to fill up the census schedule book, which is supplied to J each enumerator, are bound up in the book itself, but enumerators desirous of further it formation or advice will he able to obtain it from the Census Maawin-of the Kism in which they reside, or at the Central Census Office, Old Menshieh Tribunal, Alexandria.
Enumerators and employers of enumerators alike are asked to hear the above foots in mind, and to remember that this public duty has been laid upon the better educated section of the community only because there are not enough people able to read and write in Egypt for it to he possible to carry out the census in ‘ the same way that it is carried out in European
WELL KNOWN MINISTER DROWNED There are many in Alexandria who will learn with pain of the tragedy which occurred on board the Papayanni S.S. Ararat on her way from Liverpool to Alexandria. One of the passengers of the vessel, which arrived here yesterday, was the Rev. M T.S. Taylor, B.D., well known and respected at Alexandria, who was on his way out to join the Scottish Mission here. On enquiring for him on board yesterday a party of friends, who had gone down to the docks to meet him, were horrified to learn that the reverend gentleman had disappeared overboard during a storm io the Bay of Biscay.
Three days previous to this occurrence the ship's carpenter was swept overboard by a heavy sea and was likewise drowned. THE KHEDIVE. The Khedive, who spent yesterday at Koubbeh Palace, came this morning to Abdeen, where he presided over the Council of Ministers and officially received the new Belgian Diplomatic Agent, who presented his credentials to his Highness.
The Khedivial Ball which was to have been held on the 28th inst, and was postponed in consequence of the death of Prince Ahmed Kamei Pasha, will now (says “Al Ahram”) be held at Abdeen Palace shortly after the expiration of the period of mourning, when the Maieh will issue fresh invitations for the ball. LORD CROMER’S RETURN.
Lord and Lady Cromer returned from Upper Egypt shortly before 12 a.m. on Sunday. Both are in excellent health.
Oar Minieh Correspondent writes :—Lord Cromer arrived here yesterday (Friday) evening from his trip to Upper Egypt. accompanied by the Moudir and Mr. Hopkins, the inspector of the Interior, his lordship visited the children’s hospital, the animal infirmary, the house of Mr. Ryke, agent of the National Bank, etc. His lordship left to day (Saturday) for Cairo.
THE SPREAD OF EDUCATION.
The movement in favour of the extension of education gains ground daily. On Thursday afternoon a meeting was held at the Moudirieh of Dakahlieh and the Moudir addressed a meeting of local notables with great eloquenoe, urging them to subscribe for the foundation of a school at Mansourah, where teachers for the kuttaba, a class for which there is a very great demand, could be trained. The notables ’hen and there gave practical proof of their sym-paihy with the Moudir’s suggestion by subscribing L.E. 1,500 for this purpose. THE CAPITULATIONS.
Mr. Edward Dioey, in ‘‘The Egypt of the Future,” severely oritioises Lord Cromer’s proposals in regard to the Capitulations. In an interesting passage be remarks :—
"The decision of the Algeoiras Conference, confirming as it does the non-validity of the free hand aooorded to Franoe in' Moroooo by the Anglo-Freimh Agreement, app'iea logically to the tree baud in Egypt aooorded to England by France. ,
‘According to the precedent established at Algeciras, any European Power which has political or commercial interests or rights in Egypt would be entitled to refuse her consent to any substantial changes which England might propose to introduce into the relations between Egypt and other Continental powers, till these changes have been approved by an International Conference. There can be no reasonable doubt that it such a Conference were to meet, its first step would be to demand an explicit explanation from England as to whether she intends her military occupation to be permanent or temporary ; and, on the latter hypothesis, when the occupation was to end, or, on the former hypothesis, what guarantees were to be given for the preservation of ’he rights now possessed in Egypt by the subjects of other nations than the two parties to the free-hand agreement. If this is so, I think all British statesmen—to whatever party they may belong, or whatever their views may be as to the internal administration of Egypt—will agree with me in holding that the present moment is singularly infelicitous for proposing the formal recognition of a British Protectorate over Egypt, or for suggesting the expediency of cancelling the Capitulations and abolishing the International Tribunals.” ALEXANDRIA’S ROADS.
A motorist writes : The state of the roads in Alexandria is disgraceful. There has been a hole you could lose a horse in in the asphalte nearly outside the “Egyptian Gazette" offices since November. The asphalte of Rue Tons-soon Pasha and that by the French Consulate is as bad, while no macadamising has been done anywhere for nearly a year. Motor-owners need never. Expect sympathy, but here we get a whacking great tax for owning them, and the people who tax us leave the roads in such a state that our cars get rained in a few months. • CARLTON HOTEL

Proprietor, O. AQUILINA, (Late of thes. Cook and Sons) SATURDAY'S INAUGURATION.
The formal inauguration of the latest addition to the hotels of Alexandria, the new Savoy Palace Hotel in Rosetta-avenue, took place on Saturday last and proved a most successful 'Social function. Invitations to an ‘nt home” in the afternoon had been issued b;r the management in a liberal manner and these were so largely responded to that a continual stream of visitors, representing the rank and fashion of Alexandria, poured into the hotel from 4 to 7 p.m., the number of guests present being estimated at over 2 000.
We have, already given our readers a de tailed description of the Savoy Palace, so that it is needless to recapitulate here. Everyone, however, who visited the salons and rooms of the hotel, most of which were thrown open to the guests, were loud in their praises of the magnificent furnishings and equipment of the house, which, as we have already said, is equal to any first-class hostelry in Cairo or out of it The delightful winter garden came in for special admiration, and hire it was that the numerous guests ware regaled at a sumptuous buffet, which, notwithstanding the enormous demands on it, never seemed to feel the strain. While the guests indulged in refreshments the band of the Royal Dublin Fusiliers, under Band-master Fawcett, kindly lent for the occasion, discoursed a choice selection of music, of which ’he programme follows:—
Khedivial Hymn.
God save the King..

It was not till close on eight o’olook before the last of the guests bidden to the inauguration had left the hotel, all enchanted with what they had seen, and preparations were then made for the dinner given by the hotel directors to a number of their friends and representatives of the Press. This took place at nine o’olook, over 150 covers being laid in the beautiful dining room, which was almost dazzling with its myriads of electric lights and bright decoratlon. To say that the mann of the dinner was excellent would be according but faint praise. The Savoy Palace has manifestly acquired the services of a master of the culinary a?t, and he was evidently bent on making a success of the inaugural dinner. That he achieved this success was the unanimous verdict of all the guests. The menu is worthy of reproduction, and we give it below:—
